SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States"

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine US arms sales corruption")
web_search("Ukraine arms sales audit")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Several sources discuss corruption within Ukraine's defense sector. Al Jazeera reports that Ukrainian authorities detained officials over a "large-scale corruption scheme" involving military drones and signal jamming systems, with kickbacks up to 30 percent of contract amounts (<image:k> - [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/2/ukraine-says-defence-sector-corruption-scheme-uncovered]). Politico.eu also highlights a corruption scheme involving inflated prices for military equipment, with a 30 percent kickback, which President Zelenskyy called "absolutely immoral" - [https://www.politico.eu/article/ukraine-uncovers-major-corruption-scheme-defense-procurment-days-after-restoring-anticorruption/].

PBS.org discusses illicit weapons, high-level corruption, and organized crime in Ukraine, noting that Ukraine lost $32 billion in military assets between 1992 and 1998 due to theft, discount arms sales, and lack of oversight - [https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/sierraleone/context.html].


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Associated Press reported that the U.S. cannot track over $1 billion in weapons and military equipment provided to Ukraine, with 59% of $1.7 billion in defense gear remaining "delinquent" according to the Pentagon's inspector general. Reasons for the monitoring shortfall include limited staffing, movement restrictions, and a lack of internal inventory controls. The Department of Defense Office of Inspector General (DoD OIG) also found insufficient documentation for $1.1 billion in funds, considering these as questioned costs. <image:k>

VoxUkraine fact-checked claims that the Pentagon is demanding an audit of weapons supplied to Ukraine, stating that the supply and end-use of weapons are already monitored by partners. The article also references a report stating that Ukraine has implemented strict arms control measures.
*   [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-weapons-audit-watchdog-us-congress-biden-9abecd14528b9551ff4ddb6786ad7fda](https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-weapons-audit-watchdog-us-congress-biden-9abecd14528b9551ff4ddb6786ad7fda)
*   [https://www.dodig.mil/In-the-Spotlight/Article/3940692/press-release-audit-of-the-dods-execution-of-funds-to-assist-ukraine-report-no/](https://www.dodig.mil/In-the-Spotlight/Article/3940692/press-release-audit-of-the-dods-execution-of-funds-to-assist-ukraine-report-no/)
*   [https://voxukraine.org/en/fake-the-pentagon-demands-an-audit-of-all-weapons-supplied-to-ukraine-before-trump-s-return-wsj](https://voxukraine.org/en/fake-the-pentagon-demands-an-audit-of-all-weapons-supplied-to-ukraine-before-trump-s-return-wsj)


## Elaboration
The evidence reveals instances of corruption and a lack of complete oversight regarding the use of military aid provided to Ukraine. Reports from Al Jazeera and Politico.eu detail corruption schemes within Ukraine's defense sector, including inflated prices and kickbacks. The Associated Press indicates that the U.S. has difficulty tracking over $1 billion in weapons and equipment, with a significant portion of defense gear unaccounted for.

While there is evidence of corruption and monitoring challenges, the provided sources do not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. The evidence highlights issues with tracking and accountability, but it does not quantify the extent of any potential arms sales.

To verify the claim, information is needed on the volume of arms sales, the specific armaments involved, and the recipients of these sales.


## Actions
```

web_search("Ukraine arms sales investigation")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Reuters reports a 29% surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments in 2024, reaching a record $318.7 billion, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine (<image:9661> - [https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/ukraine-related-demand-sends-us-arms-exports-record-2024-2025-01-24/]). SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports - [https://www.sipri.org/media/press-release/2025/ukraine-worlds-biggest-arms-importer-united-states-dominance-global-arms-exports-grows-russian]. The Washington Post also notes that U.S. arms exports increased to 43% of the worldwide total between 2020 and 2024 - [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/03/09/us-arms-sales-ukraine-israel/].


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Trump administration approved an $825 million arms sale to Ukraine, including extended-range missiles, as reported by CNN and the Associated Press (<image:k>, <image:k> - [https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine), [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-us-weapons-sale-trump-russia-74e01123c0067d5fc160141e0cabf207]). The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv (<image:k> - [https://www.occrp.org/en/news/bulgaria-raids-arms-dealers-in-ukraine-led-corruption-probe]).


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. While there is evidence of corruption and a lack of complete oversight, the provided sources do not quantify the extent of any potential arms sales. Reuters reports a surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine. SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports. The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine arms sales black market")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/): 
Content: The Harvard International Review (June 19, 2024) discusses the illicit arms trade in Ukraine, highlighting concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market. It mentions Ukraine's history of a large black market for arms, with an estimated $32 billion in military equipment lost between 1992 and 1998. The article notes reports of weapons being stolen since 2022, but also warns about Russian disinformation campaigns exaggerating the issue. The US end-use monitoring program focuses on specific weapon systems, with less attention on small arms and light weapons, which are more likely to be stolen by criminal organizations.


From [Source](https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/): 
Content: The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) published an article on September 23, 2024, discussing the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine. The article mentions the sale of US-made M240 machine guns for $8,000 and Soviet-type AGS-17 automatic grenade launchers for $6,000. It also references seizures of weapons, including an anti-aircraft gun and a US machine gun. <image:1149>, <image:1150>, <image:1151>.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Harvard International Review discusses the illicit arms trade in Ukraine, highlighting concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market, referencing a history of a large black market for arms. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made M240 machine guns and Soviet-type AGS-17 automatic grenade launchers, and referencing seizures of weapons (<image:1149>, <image:1150>, <image:1151>).
*   [https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/](https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/)
*   [https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/](https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/)

### Evidence from `web_search`

The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made M240 machine guns and Soviet-type AGS-17 automatic grenade launchers, and referencing seizures of weapons (<image:1149>, <image:1150>, <image:1151>).

# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence indicates that there is an illicit arms trade in Ukraine, with concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made machine guns and Soviet-type grenade launchers. However, the evidence does not provide any data to support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States"

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Several sources discuss corruption within Ukraine's defense sector. Al Jazeera reports that Ukrainian authorities detained officials over a "large-scale corruption scheme" involving military drones and signal jamming systems, with kickbacks up to 30 percent of contract amounts (<image:k> - [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/2/ukraine-says-defence-sector-corruption-scheme-uncovered]). ### Evidence from `web_search`
The Associated Press reported that the U.S. cannot track over $1 billion in weapons and military equipment provided to Ukraine, with 59% of $1.7 billion in defense gear remaining "delinquent" according to the Pentagon's inspector general. Reasons for the monitoring shortfall include limited staffing, movement restrictions, and a lack of internal inventory controls. The Department of Defense Office of Inspector General (DoD OIG) also found insufficient documentation for $1.1 billion in funds, considering these as questioned costs. <image:k>

Reports from Al Jazeera and Politico.eu detail corruption schemes within Ukraine's defense sector, including inflated prices and kickbacks. ## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Reuters reports a 29% surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments in 2024, reaching a record $318.7 billion, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine (<image:9661> - [https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/ukraine-related-demand-sends-us-arms-exports-record-2024-2025-01-24/]). SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports - [https://www.sipri.org/media/press-release/2025/ukraine-worlds-biggest-arms-importer-united-states-dominance-global-arms-exports-grows-russian]. The Washington Post also notes that U.S. arms exports increased to 43% of the worldwide total between 2020 and 2024 - [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/03/09/us-arms-sales-ukraine-israel/].


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Trump administration approved an $825 million arms sale to Ukraine, including extended-range missiles, as reported by CNN and the Associated Press (<image:k>, <image:k> - [https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine), [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-us-weapons-sale-trump-russia-74e01123c0067d5fc160141e0cabf207]). The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv (<image:k> - [https://www.occrp.org/en/news/bulgaria-raids-arms-dealers-in-ukraine-led-corruption-probe]).


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. While there is evidence of corruption and a lack of complete oversight, the provided sources do not quantify the extent of any potential arms sales. Reuters reports a surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine. SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports. The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine arms sales black market")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Harvard International Review discusses the illicit arms trade in Ukraine, highlighting concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market, referencing a history of a large black market for arms. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made M240 machine guns and Soviet-type AGS-17 automatic grenade launchers, and referencing seizures of weapons (<image:1149>, <image:1150>, <image:1151>).
*   [https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/](https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/)
*   [https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/](https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/)

## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that there is an illicit arms trade in Ukraine, with concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made machine guns and Soviet-type grenade launchers. However, the evidence does not provide any data to support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The investigation reveals evidence of corruption, lack of oversight, and illicit arms trade in Ukraine. However, the provided sources do not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. While there are concerns about weapons theft and black market activity, there is no data to quantify the extent of any potential arms sales.

`false`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States"

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine US arms sales corruption")
web_search("Ukraine arms sales audit")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Several sources discuss corruption within Ukraine's defense sector. Al Jazeera reports that Ukrainian authorities detained officials over a "large-scale corruption scheme" involving military drones and signal jamming systems, with kickbacks up to 30 percent of contract amounts (<image:k> - [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/2/ukraine-says-defence-sector-corruption-scheme-uncovered]). Politico.eu also highlights a corruption scheme involving inflated prices for military equipment, with a 30 percent kickback, which President Zelenskyy called "absolutely immoral" - [https://www.politico.eu/article/ukraine-uncovers-major-corruption-scheme-defense-procurment-days-after-restoring-anticorruption/].

PBS.org discusses illicit weapons, high-level corruption, and organized crime in Ukraine, noting that Ukraine lost $32 billion in military assets between 1992 and 1998 due to theft, discount arms sales, and lack of oversight - [https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/sierraleone/context.html].


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Associated Press reported that the U.S. cannot track over $1 billion in weapons and military equipment provided to Ukraine, with 59% of $1.7 billion in defense gear remaining "delinquent" according to the Pentagon's inspector general. Reasons for the monitoring shortfall include limited staffing, movement restrictions, and a lack of internal inventory controls. The Department of Defense Office of Inspector General (DoD OIG) also found insufficient documentation for $1.1 billion in funds, considering these as questioned costs. <image:k>

VoxUkraine fact-checked claims that the Pentagon is demanding an audit of weapons supplied to Ukraine, stating that the supply and end-use of weapons are already monitored by partners. The article also references a report stating that Ukraine has implemented strict arms control measures.
*   [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-weapons-audit-watchdog-us-congress-biden-9abecd14528b9551ff4ddb6786ad7fda](https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-weapons-audit-watchdog-us-congress-biden-9abecd14528b9551ff4ddb6786ad7fda)
*   [https://www.dodig.mil/In-the-Spotlight/Article/3940692/press-release-audit-of-the-dods-execution-of-funds-to-assist-ukraine-report-no/](https://www.dodig.mil/In-the-Spotlight/Article/3940692/press-release-audit-of-the-dods-execution-of-funds-to-assist-ukraine-report-no/)
*   [https://voxukraine.org/en/fake-the-pentagon-demands-an-audit-of-all-weapons-supplied-to-ukraine-before-trump-s-return-wsj](https://voxukraine.org/en/fake-the-pentagon-demands-an-audit-of-all-weapons-supplied-to-ukraine-before-trump-s-return-wsj)


## Elaboration
The evidence reveals instances of corruption and a lack of complete oversight regarding the use of military aid provided to Ukraine. Reports from Al Jazeera and Politico.eu detail corruption schemes within Ukraine's defense sector, including inflated prices and kickbacks. The Associated Press indicates that the U.S. has difficulty tracking over $1 billion in weapons and equipment, with a significant portion of defense gear unaccounted for.

While there is evidence of corruption and monitoring challenges, the provided sources do not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. The evidence highlights issues with tracking and accountability, but it does not quantify the extent of any potential arms sales.

To verify the claim, information is needed on the volume of arms sales, the specific armaments involved, and the recipients of these sales.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine US arms sales percentage")
web_search("Ukraine arms sales investigation")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Reuters reports a 29% surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments in 2024, reaching a record $318.7 billion, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine (<image:9661> - [https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/ukraine-related-demand-sends-us-arms-exports-record-2024-2025-01-24/]). SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports - [https://www.sipri.org/media/press-release/2025/ukraine-worlds-biggest-arms-importer-united-states-dominance-global-arms-exports-grows-russian]. The Washington Post also notes that U.S. arms exports increased to 43% of the worldwide total between 2020 and 2024 - [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/03/09/us-arms-sales-ukraine-israel/].


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Trump administration approved an $825 million arms sale to Ukraine, including extended-range missiles, as reported by CNN and the Associated Press (<image:k>, <image:k> - [https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/28/politics/trump-missile-sale-ukraine), [https://apnews.com/article/ukraine-us-weapons-sale-trump-russia-74e01123c0067d5fc160141e0cabf207]). The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv (<image:k> - [https://www.occrp.org/en/news/bulgaria-raids-arms-dealers-in-ukraine-led-corruption-probe]).


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. While there is evidence of corruption and a lack of complete oversight, the provided sources do not quantify the extent of any potential arms sales. Reuters reports a surge in U.S. military equipment sales to foreign governments, with demand driven by countries replenishing stocks sent to Ukraine. SIPRI indicates that Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer in 2020–24, with the U.S. supplying 45% of its major arms imports. The OCCRP reports that Bulgarian authorities searched arms dealers' homes and offices due to a Ukrainian investigation into alleged overpricing in arms sales to Kyiv.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine arms sales black market")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Harvard International Review discusses the illicit arms trade in Ukraine, highlighting concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market, referencing a history of a large black market for arms. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made M240 machine guns and Soviet-type AGS-17 automatic grenade launchers, and referencing seizures of weapons (<image:1149>, <image:1150>, <image:1151>).
*   [https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/](https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/)
*   [https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/](https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/)

## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that there is an illicit arms trade in Ukraine, with concerns about weapons theft and circulation on the black market. The Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime (GI-TOC) discusses the rise of arms trafficking in Ukraine, mentioning the sale of US-made machine guns and Soviet-type grenade launchers. However, the evidence does not provide any data to support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States.


## Final Judgement
The investigation reveals evidence of corruption, lack of oversight, and illicit arms trade in Ukraine. However, the provided sources do not support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. While there are concerns about weapons theft and black market activity, there is no data to quantify the extent of any potential arms sales.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The investigation found evidence of corruption and a black market for arms in Ukraine, but no evidence to support the claim that Ukraine is selling half of the armaments it receives from the United States. Sources like the [Harvard International Review](https://hir.harvard.edu/facts-or-false-alarms-the-state-of-illicit-arms-in-ukraine/) and the [Global Initiative Against Transnational Organized Crime](https://globalinitiative.net/analysis/a-new-phase-of-arms-trafficking-in-ukraine/) highlight illicit arms trade, but do not provide data on the volume of sales.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: geolocate()

...

```

```

```

* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

FSWC Calls for Canadians to Stand with Israel
---------------------------------------------

October 7, 2023
---------------

### News Release

[< Back to News Room](/news)

! <image:1348>

‍

**Statement from FSWC**

**Toronto (October 7, 2023)** - Friends of Simon Wiesenthal Center (FSWC) is devastated by today’s horrific news from Israel concerning the many Israelis killed or wounded in the murderous, multi-front assault by Hamas terrorists.

We extend our condolences and deepest sympathies to the families of those killed in this abhorrent, unprovoked attack on civilians. We express our wishes for a full and speedy recovery to those wounded and pray for the safe return of all those kidnapped and taken to Gaza as hostages by the Hamas invaders.

We condemn, in the harshest terms, the actions of Palestinian terror groups in firing thousands of rockets indiscriminately at civilian targets in Israel and massacring residents in numerous villages and towns, actions that constitute heinous war crimes that shouldn’t go unpunished.

FSWC thanks senior police officials in Toronto, York and Peel regions after they informed us that they have devoted additional resources to ensure the safety and security of Jewish residents and Jewish community institutions given the antisemitic attacks that took place two years ago in Toronto during the last major conflict between Israel and Palestinian terror groups in Gaza.

**FSWC President and CEO Michael Levitt issued the following statement:**

“We appreciate the strong support for Israel already expressed by leaders in our country, including the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and many others at all levels of government and many community organizations. We call on all Canadians to stand in solidarity with Israel, to unequivocally condemn today’s appalling attacks against Israelis and to speak out against the actions of the Palestinian terrorists and those who support them, including their backers in Iran.”

‍

‍

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Times of Israel published an article on October 7, 2023, about the Hamas attack on Israel. The article includes images of the aftermath of the attacks, including burning vehicles and buildings. <image:20> is found in the article. The article does not mention a US drone being shot down by the Houthis using Russian missiles.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim

## Actions

reverse_search(<image:20>)

```

## Web Sources

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:20> This image shows a US drone which was shot down in March 2025 by the Houthis using Russian missiles."

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:20>)
reverse_search(<image:20>)
web_search("drone shot down Houthis Russian missiles")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/): 
Content: "##### Share

Close

[Mail](mailto:?subject=How the Houthis’ strikes on US MQ-9 Reaper drones serve a wider regional agenda&body=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/ "Share by Email")
 [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.atlanticcouncil.org%2Fblogs%2Fmenasource%2Fhouthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones%2F "Share on Facebook")
 [Twitter / X](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.atlanticcouncil.org%2Fblogs%2Fmenasource%2Fhouthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones%2F&text=How+the+Houthis%E2%80%99+strikes+on+US+MQ-9+Reaper+drones+serve+a+wider+regional+agenda "Share on Twitter")
 [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/&text=How+the+Houthis%E2%80%99+strikes+on+US+MQ-9+Reaper+drones+serve+a+wider+regional+agenda [https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/] "Share on LinkedIn")

On December 28, 2024, Yahya Sare’e, the spokesperson for the Houthis, [announced](https://x.com/AmeenHa2024yan/status/1873057956704731540)
 that a Houthi surface-to-air missile shot down a US MQ-9 Reaper unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) overflying the Al Bayda governorate in Yemen. Despite their protracted deployment, the number of US drones lost to hostile fire was minimal, with only three MQ-9 Reapers shot down by the Houthis between [2017](https://www.popularmechanics.com/military/aviation/news/a28469/us-reaper-drone-shot-down-over-yemen/)
 and [2019](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-usa-drone-idUSKCN1VB180/)
.

During the Houthis’ anti-shipping campaign, there has been a marked escalation in the group’s tactical proficiency against US drones. Four days later, the Houthis [boasted](https://x.com/AmeenHa2024yan/status/1874346837530087576)
 the downing of a second US-made drone in the Marib governorate, marking the first Houthi strike of an MQ-9 Reaper in 2025.

These attacks represent the latest in a long string of successful Houthi strikes against US UAVs since the beginning of the Israel-Hamas war, showcasing the Houthis’ growing offensive capabilities. 

For the Yemeni militant group, imposing a heavy toll on the US drone fleet serves tactical, strategic, and symbolic goals at the domestic and regional levels. The strikes against MQ-9 Reaper drones impair US intelligence and targeting systems and help the Houthis shore up domestic and regional support. And, with the Houthis’ ties to China, Russia, and Iran, downed MQ-9 Reaper drones could end up in the hands of US adversaries. 

Given the benefits the Houthis continue to enjoy from shooting down these drones, the United States needs to adjust its drone deployment strategy to ensure that MQ-9 Reapers are less vulnerable to the militant group’s attacks. 

#### **The offensive**

The surge of attacks on US UAVs and the anti-shipping campaign are major pieces of the Houthi’s latest offensive. Since November 2023, the Houthis [have claimed](https://english.almasirah.net.ye/post/44879/)
 responsibility for downing fourteen MQ-9 Reaper drones, in a series of attacks that have targeted US assets primarily in Marib and Sa’ada governorates. However, those designs are either variants of Iranian weapon systems or based on Iran’s technology, such as the Sayyad-2C (Hunter) missile, the Saqr series (Iran’s 358 missile), and the Barq missile family (Iran’s Taer series). 

#### **Inside the Houthis’ strategy**

Tactically, the Houthi shootdowns of MQ-9 drones primarily aim to blind the US intelligence and targeting systems. The Houthis’ efforts to conceal strategic sites have heightened the Western coalition’s dependence on UAVs to collect actionable intelligence on military installations.

For the Houthis, the shootdowns of US drones also hold symbolic value. Factual or not, these claims serve to inflate the Houthis’ perceived combat strength and burnish their image as a militia capable of confronting US forces head-on.

#### **The Houthis’ dangerous partners**

Although the MQ-9 Reapers have been shot down over Yemen, the negative ramifications of these Houthi attacks on US military assets could spill over beyond the country’s borders. In addition, US intelligence revealed that [Iran mediated talks](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/iran-brokering-talks-send-advanced-russian-missiles-yemens-houthis-sources-say-2024-09-24/)
between Russia and the Houthis that led to Moscow supplying Russian-made advanced anti-ship cruise missiles to the group. For instance, in mid-2019, Iran [rushed](https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5529508,00.html)
 to retrieve a US Navy MQ-4C Triton that the IRGC [shot down](https://www.reuters.com/article/markets/commodities/iran-shoots-down-us-military-drone-in-gulf-region-idUSL8N23R09Y/)
 over the Strait of Hormuz."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Atlantic Council reports that the Houthis have shot down US MQ-9 Reaper drones. The Houthis claimed to have shot down a US MQ-9 Reaper in the Al Bayda governorate in Yemen on December 28, 2024. Four days later, the Houthis claimed to have downed a second US-made drone in the Marib governorate, marking the first Houthi strike of an MQ-9 Reaper in 2025. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for downing fourteen MQ-9 Reaper drones since November 2023. The article mentions that Iran mediated talks between Russia and the Houthis that led to Moscow supplying Russian-made advanced anti-ship cruise missiles to the group.

_________________________

* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements

Additional rules:

* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/04/25/nx-s1-5377192/houthis-reaper-drones-us-military-yemen): 
Content: "has increased its attacks on the Houthis, launching daily strikes since March 15, when President Donald Trump ordered a new, expanded campaign.**

### [Middle East](https://www.npr.org/sections/middle-east/)

Houthi rebels have shot down 7 US Reaper drones worth $200 million in recent weeks
==================================================================================

  

April 25, 20251:17 AM ET

By 

[The Associated Press](https://www.npr.org/people/101453150/the-associated-press)

  !Houthi supporters chant slogans during a weekly, anti-U.S. Reaper drones in less than six weeks, a loss of aircraft worth more than $200 million in what is becoming the most dramatic cost to the Pentagon of the military campaign against the Iran-backed militants.

### [State of the World from NPR](https://www.npr.org/podcasts/510366/state-of-the-world)

### [The Opaque War Against the Houthis in Yemen](https://www.npr.org/2025/04/04/1242780103/the-opaque-war-against-the-houthis-in-yemen)

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
NPR reports that Houthi rebels have shot down 7 US Reaper drones in recent weeks. The article is dated April 25, 2025, and was written by The Associated Press. <image:9764>

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:20> This image shows a US drone which was shot down in March 2025 by the Houthis using Russian missiles."

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:20>)
reverse_search(<image:20>)
web_search("drone shot down Houthis Russian missiles")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Sea_crisis): 
Content: "Anyone who can do that can easily deny the connection between what is happening in the Red Sea and Gaza."[\[203\]](#cite_note-211)

### Operation Prosperity Guardian: American-led military coalition

While the US Navy has shot down Houthi rockets and missiles in the Red Sea, it has not retaliated against those firing them.[\[204\]](#cite_note-212)
[\[205\]](#cite_note-EscortTalk-213)
 In December 2023, after discussions with allies, the US announced the creation of a multilateral naval task force of protective escorts for commercial vessels in the Bab-el-Mandeb strait and [Gulf of Aden](/wiki/Gulf_of_Aden "Gulf of Aden")
 region.[\[205\]](#cite_note-EscortTalk-213)
 The operation, codenamed [Operation Prosperity Guardian](/wiki/Operation_Prosperity_Guardian "Operation Prosperity Guardian")
,[\[206\]](#cite_note-214)
 was formally launched on 23 December 2023.[\[176\]](#cite_note-Gronholt-pedersen-184)
 It is similar to past operations protecting commercial vessels from attack, including in the [Persian Gulf](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian Gulf")
 and [Strait of Hormuz](/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz "Strait of Hormuz")
 during the "[Tanker War](/wiki/Tanker_War "Tanker War")
" of the 1980s,[\[205\]](#cite_note-EscortTalk-213)
 and the ongoing maritime security operations of [Combined Task Force 153](/wiki/Combined_Task_Force_153 "Combined Task Force 153")
, the US Navy-led task force based in [Bahrain](/wiki/Bahrain "Bahrain")
.[\[164\]](#cite_note-Wintour2023-172)
 The operation has also been compared to the successful multilateral naval campaign a decade earlier to combat [Somali pirates off the Horn of Africa](/wiki/Piracy_off_the_coast_of_Somalia "Piracy off the coast of Somalia")
, although the Houthis, unlike the Somali pirates, enjoy Iranian support, and better equipment and technology, such as helicopters, drones, missiles, and speedboats.[\[207\]](#cite_note-215)

#### Independent naval patrols for maritime security

France, Italy and India have all independently sent naval assets to the region, with the [French frigate _Languedoc_](/wiki/French_frigate_Languedoc "French frigate Languedoc")
 intercepting drones launched from a Houthi-controlled port while Italy has sent the frigate [_Virginio Fasan_](/wiki/Italian_frigate_Virginio_Fasan_(F_591) "Italian frigate Virginio Fasan (F 591)")
 under the Secure Mediterranean operation.[\[16\]](#cite_note-itdec-20)
 India has also sent two [_Kolkata_\-class destroyers](/wiki/Kolkata-class_destroyer "Kolkata-class destroyer")
 to strengthen maritime security in the Red Sea.[\[20\]](#cite_note-HT19dec-24)

### Pro-Palestinian protests

Main article: [Gaza war protests](/wiki/Gaza_war_protests "Gaza war protests")

In mid-January 2024, reports indicated that pro-Palestinian demonstrators in London voiced support for Houthi militants.     [\[18\]](#cite_note-22)

68 African migrants killed, 47 injured[\[77\]](#cite_note-85)
  
3 Russian civilians injured[\[78\]](#cite_note-86)
  
6 Egyptian civilians wounded  
5 Palestinian civilians wounded[\[79\]](#cite_note-87)

Two ships have been hijacked and 36 crew members have been taken hostage by Houthi militants; one ship and 11 crew members[\[80\]](#cite_note-88)
 remain in Houthi custody, while one ship and 25 hostages have been released. Houthi leader [Abdul-Malik al-Houthi](/wiki/Abdul-Malik_al-Houthi "Abdul-Malik al-Houthi")
 warned the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")
 against intervening in support of Israel, threatening that such an intervention would be met with retaliation by drone and missile strikes.[\[104\]](#cite_note-AP20231019-112)
 In order to end their attacks in the [Red Sea](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red Sea")
, the Houthis demanded a ceasefire in the Gaza war and an end to the accompanying [Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip](/wiki/2023_Israeli_blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip "2023 Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip")
.[\[105\]](#cite_note-113)
[\[106\]](#cite_note-114)
[\[90\]](#cite_note-cnn20231209-98)

### Weapons used by Houthi militants

According to [Armament Research Services](/wiki/Armament_Research_Services "Armament Research Services")
, Houthi weapons are mostly of Russian, Chinese or Iranian origin.[\[107\]](#cite_note-115)
[\[108\]](#cite_note-116)
 They are known to use [surface-to-surface missiles](/wiki/Surface-to-surface_missile "Surface-to-surface missile")
, [artillery rockets](/wiki/Artillery_rocket "Artillery rocket")
, [loitering munitions](/wiki/Loitering_munition "Loitering munition")
 and [unmanned aerial vehicles](/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle "Unmanned aerial vehicle")
 (UAVs).[\[109\]](#cite_note-117)
 They have several missiles and UAVs capable of reaching Israel from Yemen:

*   [Toufan](/w/index.php?title=Toufan_(missile)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Toufan (missile) (page does not exist)")
     – a [surface-to-surface missile](/wiki/Surface-to-surface_missile "Surface-to-surface missile")
    , with a range of 1,800 km (1,100 mi).[\[110\]](#cite_note-amwaj-118)
    
*   [Cruise missiles](/wiki/Cruise_missile "Cruise missile")
     – from the Iranian [Soumar](/wiki/Soumar_(missile) "Soumar (missile)")
     family, with strike ranges of about 2,000 km (1,200 mi).[\[110\]](#cite_note-amwaj-118)
    
*   [Quds-2 missile](/wiki/Quds_cruise_missile#Quds-2 "Quds cruise missile")
     – supposedly with a range of 1,350 km (840 mi) but made to strike Israel.[\[111\]](#cite_note-mei-119)
    
*   [Samad-3](/wiki/Samad_(UAV) "Samad (UAV)")
     and [Samad-4](/wiki/Samad_(UAV) "Samad (UAV)")
     – UAVs/loitering munitions with ranges of 1,800 km (1,100 mi) and further.[\[111\]](#cite_note-mei-119)
    
*   [Wa'id drones](/w/index.php?title=Wa%27id_drones&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wa'id drones (page does not exist)")
     – similar to Iran's [Shahed 136](/wiki/Shahed_136 "Shahed 136")
    , loitering munition with a range of 2,500 km (1,600 mi).[\[111\]](#cite_note-mei-119)
    
*   [Naval drones](/wiki/Naval_drone "Naval drone")
     – 7 metres (23 ft) unmanned surface vessels (USVs) laden with explosives.[\[112\]](#cite_note-120)
    [\[113\]](#cite_note-121)

Houthi attacks on commercial vessels
------------------------------------

Main article: [Houthi attacks on commercial vessels](/wiki/Houthi_attacks_on_commercial_vessels "Houthi attacks on commercial vessels")

Houthi forces began attacking shipping vessels affiliated with [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 passing through the Red Sea on 19 November 2023. The video game's developers, [Bohemia Interactive](/wiki/Bohemia_Interactive "Bohemia Interactive")
, said that action taken against the videos was ineffective, saying: "With every video flagged, debunked, or taken down, ten more can be uploaded each day."[\[122\]](#cite_note-cbsnews20240605-130)
 Footage from the video game has also been misrepresented as attacks on shipping[\[128\]](#cite_note-136)
 and a US fighter jet being shot down by the Houthis over Sanaa.[\[129\]](#cite_note-137)

### Foreign involvement

See also: [Houthis § Alleged Iranian, North Korean, Russian and Chinese support](/wiki/Houthis#Alleged_Iranian,_North_Korean,_Russian_and_Chinese_support "Houthis")

#### Iran

_[Reuters](/wiki/Reuters "Reuters")
_, citing [unnamed Iranian sources](/wiki/Anonymous_source "Anonymous source")
 and "a security official close to Iran", has claimed that Iranian personnel are in Yemen, working with [Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
 militants. An insurance group earlier stated that an Iranian-made missile was used after examining debris aboard the vessel.[\[133\]](#cite_note-Noor-141)
[\[134\]](#cite_note-142)

[NBC News](/wiki/NBC_News "NBC News")
, citing two US officials, reported in September 2024 that Iran was directly assisting the Houthis with targeting and attacking American [MQ-9 Reaper](/wiki/General_Atomics_MQ-9_Reaper "General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper")
 drones, several of which were shot down or damaged during the Red Sea crisis. ^ [_**a**_](#cite_ref-fn1_9-0)
     [_**b**_](#cite_ref-fn1_9-1)
     Saudi Arabia and Egypt have not joined the coalition against the Houthis, but they have shot down Houthi missiles over their own territory.
4. strikes on Iran](/wiki/United_States_strikes_on_Iranian_nuclear_sites "United States strikes on Iranian nuclear sites")<br>        <br>    *   [Evin prison strikes](/wiki/Israeli_strikes_on_Evin_prison "Israeli strikes on Evin prison")<br>        <br>    *   [Al Udeid Air Base strikes](/wiki/2025_Iranian_strikes_on_Al_Udeid_Air_Base "2025 Iranian strikes on Al Udeid Air Base")<br>        <br>    *   [Ceasefire](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_war_ceasefire "Iran–Israel war ceasefire")<br>        <br><br>Yemen and the Red Sea<br><br>*   Red Sea crisis<br> "Attacks on the MV Maersk Hangzhou")<br>        <br>    *   [_Chem Pluto_](/wiki/2023_attack_on_the_Chem_Pluto "2023 attack on the Chem Pluto")<br>        <br>    *   [_Marlin Luanda_](/wiki/Marlin_Luanda_missile_strike "Marlin Luanda missile strike")<br>        <br>    *   [_Eternity C_](/wiki/Attacks_on_the_Eternity_C "Attacks on the Eternity C")<br>        <br>* _Sounion_](/wiki/Attacks_on_the_Sounion "Attacks on the Sounion")<br>    <br>*   [September 2024 Israeli attack](/wiki/29_September_2024_Israeli_attacks_on_Yemen "29 September 2024 Israeli attacks on Yemen")<br>    <br>*   [December 2024 Israeli airstrikes in Yemen](/wiki/December_2024_Israeli_airstrikes_in_Yemen "December 2024 Israeli airstrikes in Yemen")<br>    <br>*   [10 January 2025 Israeli attack on Yemen](/wiki/10_January_2025_Israeli_attack_on_Yemen "10 January 2025 Israeli attack on Yemen")<br>    <br>*   [March–May 2025 United States attacks in Yemen](/wiki/March%E2%80%93May_2025_United_States_attacks_in_Yemen "March–May 2025 United States attacks in Yemen")<br>    *   [2025 U.S.–Houthi ceasefire](/wiki/2025_U.S.%E2%80%93Houthi_ceasefire "2025 U.S.–Houthi ceasefire")<br>        <br>*   [2025 Houthi attack on Tel Aviv airport](/wiki/2025_Houthi_attack_on_Tel_Aviv_airport "2025 Houthi attack on Tel Aviv airport")<br>    <br>*   [May 2025–present Israeli attacks on Yemen](/wiki/Israeli_attacks_on_Yemen_(May_2025%E2%80%93present) "Israeli attacks on Yemen (May 2025–present)")<br>    *   [28 August 2025 Israeli attack](/wiki/28_August_2025_Israeli_attack_on_Yemen "28 August 2025 Israeli attack on Yemen")<br>        <br><br>Deaths<br><br>*   [Alim Abdallah](/wiki/Alim_Abdallah "Alim Abdallah")<br>    <br>*   [Issam Abdallah](/wiki/Issam_Abdallah "Issam Abdallah")<br>    <br>*   [Saleh al-Arouri](/wiki/Saleh_al-Arouri "Saleh al-Arouri")<br>    <br>*   [Ali Hussein Barji](/wiki/Ali_Hussein_Barji "Ali Hussein Barji")<br>    <br>*   [Razi Mousavi](/wiki/Razi_Mousavi "Razi Mousavi")<br>    <br>*   [Wissam al-Tawil](/wiki/Wissam_al-Tawil "Wissam al-Tawil")<br>    <br>*   [Sadegh Omidzadeh](/wiki/Sadegh_Omidzadeh "Sadegh Omidzadeh")<br>    <br>*   [Mushtaq Talib Al-Saeedi](/wiki/Mushtaq_Talib_Al-Saeedi "Mushtaq Talib Al-Saeedi")<br>    <br>*   [Mohammad Reza Zahedi](/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Zahedi "Mohammad Reza Zahedi")<br>    <br>*   [Fuad Shukr](/wiki/Fuad_Shukr "Fuad Shukr")<br>    <br>*   [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")<br>    <br>*   [Ibrahim Aqil](/wiki/Ibrahim_Aqil "Ibrahim Aqil")<br>    <br><br>Related topics<br><br>*   [Iran–Israel proxy conflict](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict "Iran–Israel proxy conflict")<br>    <br>*   [Hezbollah–Israel conflict](/wiki/Hezbollah%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Hezbollah–Israel conflict") |     |

The **Red Sea crisis** ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language")
: أزمة البحر الأحمر) began on 19 October 2023, when the [Iran-backed](/wiki/Iranian_support_for_the_Houthis "Iranian support for the Houthis")
 [Houthis](/wiki/Houthis "Houthis")
 in [Yemen](/wiki/Yemen "Yemen")
 launched missiles and armed drones at [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
, demanding an end to the [invasion of the Gaza Strip](/wiki/Israeli_invasion_of_the_Gaza_Strip "Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip")
.[\[84\]](#cite_note-aljazeera20231219-92)
[\[85\]](#cite_note-AP14Jun2024-93)
 The Houthis have since [seized or bombarded dozens of merchant and naval vessels](/wiki/Houthi_attacks_on_commercial_vessels "Houthi attacks on commercial vessels")
 in the [Red Sea](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red Sea")
 and received hundreds of retaliatory air strikes by the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")
 and allied forces.[\[86\]](#cite_note-Diakun-94)
 The crisis is linked to the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
, the [Iran–Israel proxy war](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_war "Iran–Israel proxy war")
, and the [Yemeni crisis](/wiki/Yemeni_crisis "Yemeni crisis")
.[\[87\]](#cite_note-Proxy_War-95)
[\[88\]](#cite_note-theguardian20240103-96)
[\[89\]](#cite_note-cnbc20240103-97)

Since 2014, the Houthis, who oppose [Yemen's internationally recognized government](/wiki/Presidential_Leadership_Council "Presidential Leadership Council")
, have controlled a considerable swath of the country's territory along the Red Sea. The sources also stated that Iran has escalated its provision of advanced drones, anti-ship cruise missiles, precision-strike ballistic missiles, and medium-range missiles to the Houthis, since the outbreak of the Gaza war.[\[3\]](#cite_note-hez-4)

US officials told _[Semafor](/wiki/Semafor_(website) "Semafor (website)")
_ that commanders and advisors from Iran's [Revolutionary Guards](/wiki/Revolutionary_Guards "Revolutionary Guards")
 are currently stationed in Yemen, and are directly involved in the Houthi attacks on commercial traffic in the Red Sea. The [Qods Force](/wiki/Qods_Force "Qods Force")
, has overseen the transfer of the attack drones, cruise missiles, and medium-range ballistic missiles which have been used in the strikes on Red Sea and Israeli targets in recent weeks.[\[1\]](#cite_note-semafor-2)

According to Western intelligence officials, the Iranian [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 placed an intelligence gathering ship to guide Houthi attacks on ships that switch off radios and identifiers.[\[130\]](#cite_note-138)
 According to the Institute for the Study of War, this was likely [MV _Behshad_](/wiki/MV_Behshad "MV Behshad")
, which had replaced [MV _Saviz_](/wiki/MV_Saviz "MV Saviz")
 (which had been used to supply weapons and intelligence to the Houthis until it came under an Israeli [limpet mine](/wiki/Limpet_mine "Limpet mine")
 attack in April 2021).[\[131\]](#cite_note-139)
 The [Iranian](/wiki/Iranian_Navy "Iranian Navy")
 frigate [_Alborz_](/wiki/IRIS_Alborz_(72) "IRIS Alborz (72)")
 later also entered the Red Sea.[\[132\]](#cite_note-Al_Arabiya_English-140)

In July 2024, the [Defense Intelligence Agency](/wiki/Defense_Intelligence_Agency "Defense Intelligence Agency")
 reported that the Houthis used an Iranian-made missile in their attack on the Norwegian-flagged _Strinda_ on 11 December 2023. The officials did not elaborate on how Iran was helping the Houthis, but Michael Knights of the American think tank [Washington Institute for Near East Policy](/wiki/The_Washington_Institute_for_Near_East_Policy "The Washington Institute for Near East Policy")
 said the Houthis received Iranian surface-to-air missiles, such as the [358](/wiki/358_missile "358 missile")
 and [SA-2](/wiki/S-75_Dvina "S-75 Dvina")
, that allowed them to improve their air defenses and target US drones.[\[135\]](#cite_note-143)

#### North Korea

[Voice of America](/wiki/Voice_of_America "Voice of America")
 reported that [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea")
 may have shipped weapons to the Houthis via Iran based on [Hangul](/wiki/Hangul "Hangul")
 writing that was found on Houthi-launched missiles.[\[136\]](#cite_note-North_Korea-144)

#### China

Two China-based companies were sanctioned by the US in 2024 for providing "dual-use materials and components needed to manufacture, maintain, and deploy an arsenal of advanced missiles and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) against U.S."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses the Red Sea crisis, which began in October 2023. It mentions the Houthis, supported by Iran, launching attacks on vessels in the Red Sea and receiving retaliatory strikes from the US and allies. The Houthis use weapons of Russian, Chinese, or Iranian origin, including missiles and UAVs. The article also mentions the US Navy shooting down Houthi rockets and missiles in the Red Sea. The timeline includes events such as the beginning of Operation Prosperity Guardian in December 2023 and US airstrikes in March 2025. The article also mentions that footage from video games has been misrepresented as attacks on shipping and a US fighter jet being shot down by the Houthis.

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:20> This image shows a US drone which was shot down in March 2025 by the Houthis using Russian missiles."

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:20>)
reverse_search(<image:20>)
web_search("drone shot down Houthis Russian missiles")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/): 
Content: The Atlantic Council reports that the Houthis have shot down US MQ-9 Reaper drones. The Houthis claimed to have shot down a US MQ-9 Reaper in the Al Bayda governorate in Yemen on December 28, 2024. Four days later, the Houthis claimed to have downed a second US-made drone in the Marib governorate, marking the first Houthi strike of an MQ-9 Reaper in 2025. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for downing fourteen MQ-9 Reaper drones since November 2023. The article mentions that Iran mediated talks between Russia and the Houthis that led to Moscow supplying Russian-made advanced anti-ship cruise missiles to the group.


From [Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/04/25/nx-s1-5377192/houthis-reaper-drones-us-military-yemen): 
Content: NPR reports that Houthi rebels have shot down 7 US Reaper drones in recent weeks. The article is dated April 25, 2025, and was written by The Associated Press. <image:9764>


From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Sea_crisis): 
Content: The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses the Red Sea crisis, which began in October 2023. It mentions the Houthis, supported by Iran, launching attacks on vessels in the Red Sea and receiving retaliatory strikes from the US and allies. The Houthis use weapons of Russian, Chinese, or Iranian origin, including missiles and UAVs. The article also mentions the US Navy shooting down Houthi rockets and missiles in the Red Sea. The timeline includes events such as the beginning of Operation Prosperity Guardian in December 2023 and US airstrikes in March 2025. The article also mentions that footage from video games has been misrepresented as attacks on shipping and a US fighter jet being shot down by the Houthis.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Atlantic Council reports that the Houthis have shot down US MQ-9 Reaper drones, with the Houthis claiming to have downed fourteen MQ-9 Reaper drones since November 2023. The article mentions that Iran mediated talks between Russia and the Houthis that led to Moscow supplying Russian-made advanced anti-ship cruise missiles to the group. [Source](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/houthi-strikes-on-us-mq9-reaper-drones/)

NPR reports that Houthi rebels have shot down 7 US Reaper drones in recent weeks. [Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/04/25/nx-s1-5377192/houthis-reaper-drones-us-military-yemen) The Wikipedia article discusses the Red Sea crisis, which began in October 2023, and mentions the Houthis launching attacks on vessels in the Red Sea and receiving retaliatory strikes from the US and allies. The Houthis use weapons of Russian, Chinese, or Iranian origin, including missiles and UAVs. The article also mentions the US Navy shooting down Houthi rockets and missiles in the Red Sea. [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Sea_crisis) <image:9764>

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

The article mentions that Iran mediated talks between Russia and the Houthis that led to Moscow supplying Russian-made advanced anti-ship cruise missiles to the group. # Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence suggests that the Houthis have shot down US MQ-9 Reaper drones. The Atlantic Council reports that the Houthis have claimed to have downed fourteen MQ-9 Reaper drones since November 2023. The NPR article states that the Houthis have shot down 7 US Reaper drones in recent weeks. The Wikipedia article mentions that the Houthis use weapons of Russian, Chinese, or Iranian origin, including missiles and UAVs.

The image's location is most likely in Israel. The claim states that the image shows a US drone shot down by the Houthis. However, the evidence does not confirm the image's origin or the type of aircraft involved.

The claim is partially supported by the evidence, as the Houthis have shot down US drones. However, the evidence does not confirm that the image depicts a US drone shot down by the Houthis. More information is needed to verify the claim.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Instructions

* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/15/us/drone-sightings-east-coast): 
Content: "The flying objects have been spotted over residential neighborhoods, restricted sites and critical infrastructure.

The sightings have put intense pressure on [federal agencies](https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/15/politics/mysterious-drone-sightings-lawmakers-criticize-response/index.html)
 to provide more information about the aircraft, as officials have urged calm and emphasized there is no evidence suggesting the sightings pose a security threat.

The Biden administration has not identified “anything anomalous or any national security or public safety risks over the civilian airspace in New Jersey or other states in the Northeast,” White House National Security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters Monday.

“We assess that the sightings to date include a combination of lawful commercial drones, hobbyist drones and law enforcement drones, as well as manned fixed-wing aircrafts, helicopters, and even stars that were mistakenly reported as drones,” Kirby said. [](#maincontent)

Are drones spotted over NJ dangerous? Hear what one expert thinks

04:21 \- Source: [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Video Ad Feedback

Are drones spotted over NJ dangerous? And calls for military intervention.

This isn’t the plot of “War of the Worlds,” but rather the result of numerous possible drone sightings in recent weeks. While the FBI is still checking out 100 or so tips, none of them appear nefarious, he said.

“I can’t rule out the fact that we might find some sort of illegal or criminal activity, some nefarious activity, (but) all I can do is tell you that right now we see none of that,” Kirby said.

The US is sending drone detection and tracking systems to two military facilities in New Jersey, according to three defense officials Monday. The systems are in the process of moving to Picatinny Arsenal, a US military research facility, in northern New Jersey and Naval Weapons Station Earle in central New Jersey, the officials said.

Drones have been spotted near [Picatinny Arsenal](https://x.com/USNorthernCmd/status/1866933937467166857)
 and over President-elect Donald Trump’s golf course in Bedminster, according to [military officials](https://x.com/USNorthernCmd/status/1866933937467166857)
 and [state lawmakers](https://x.com/SenBooker/status/1866607594837848396/photo/1)
. The sightings prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue temporary flight restrictions over the properties.

“Several instances of unidentified drones entering the airspace” were also reported above [Naval Weapons Station Earle](https://cnrma.cnic.navy.mil/Installations/NWS-Earle/)
, a US Navy base south of Middletown, although no direct threats were identified.

New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy received a briefing from the FBI on Sunday night regarding the drone sighting investigation around Naval Weapons Station Earle, he said in [a post on X](https://x.com/GovMurphy/status/1868499153153855491)
."

     from the first crashed drone
*   Hand over the first [SAS disk](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_1 "UAV SAS disk 1")
     to [Peacekeeper](/wiki/Peacekeeper "Peacekeeper")
    
*   Locate the second UAV crash site on [Shoreline](/wiki/Shoreline "Shoreline")
    
*   Obtain the [SAS disk](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_2 "UAV SAS disk 2")
     from the second crashed drone
*   Hand over the second [SAS disk](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_2 "UAV SAS disk 2")
     to [Peacekeeper](/wiki/Peacekeeper "Peacekeeper")
    

Rewards\[[](https://auth.fandom.com/signin?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fescapefromtarkov.fandom.com%2Fwiki%2FEagle_Eye%3Faction%3Dedit%26section%3D4&uselang=en "Sign in to edit")\
\]
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*   +6,600 [EXP](/wiki/EXP "EXP")
    
*   [Peacekeeper](/wiki/Peacekeeper "Peacekeeper")
     Rep **+0.03**
*   900 Dollars
    *   945 Dollars with [Intelligence Center](/wiki/Hideout#Modules "Hideout")
         Level 1
    *   1,035 Dollars with [Intelligence Center](/wiki/Hideout#Modules "Hideout")
         Level 2
*   1× [ELCAN SpecterDR 1x/4x scope (FDE)](/wiki/ELCAN_SpecterDR_1x/4x_scope_(FDE) "ELCAN SpecterDR 1x/4x scope (FDE)")
    
*   1× [Leupold Mark 4 HAMR 4x24 DeltaPoint hybrid assault scope](/wiki/Leupold_Mark_4_HAMR_4x24_DeltaPoint_hybrid_assault_scope "Leupold Mark 4 HAMR 4x24 DeltaPoint hybrid assault scope")
    
*   Unlocks purchase of [SIG MPX 9x19 submachine gun](/wiki/SIG_MPX_9x19_submachine_gun "SIG MPX 9x19 submachine gun")
     at [Peacekeeper](/wiki/Peacekeeper "Peacekeeper")
     LL2

Your promptness is amazing, great job! Marvelous, here's your reward.

Guide\[[](https://auth.fandom.com/signin?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fescapefromtarkov.fandom.com%2Fwiki%2FEagle_Eye%3Faction%3Dedit%26section%3D5&uselang=en "Sign in to edit")\
\]

| [![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_1 "UAV SAS disk 1") | [UAV SAS disk #1](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_1 "UAV SAS disk 1") | 1   | Handover item | Yes | _This [quest item](/wiki/Quests#Quest_items "Quests")<br> can only be found if the quest is active._  <br>_When picked up, this item is transferred to the player's quest item inventory._  <br>_If the player fails to extract with this item, they will lose it._ |
| [![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_2 "UAV SAS disk 2") | [UAV SAS disk #2](/wiki/UAV_SAS_disk_2 "UAV SAS disk 2") | 1   | Handover item | Yes | _This [quest item](/wiki/Quests#Quest_items "Quests")<br> can only be found if the quest is active._  <br>_When picked up, this item is transferred to the player's quest item inventory._  <br>_If the player fails to extract with this item, they will lose it._ |

In this quest you have to obtain two disks from crashed UAV drones on [Shoreline](/wiki/Shoreline "Shoreline")
.

*   *   [!Drones marked on map <image:9791>](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/escapefromtarkov_gamepedia/images/2/20/Eagle_Eye_Locations.png/revision/latest?cb=20240116180139 "Drones marked on map")
        
        Drones marked on map
        
    *   [!The first UAV is located near the smuggler base <image:9792>](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/escapefromtarkov_gamepedia/images/c/c2/Firstshorelineuav.png/revision/latest?cb=20231228222816 "The first UAV is located near the smuggler base")
        
        The first UAV is located near the smuggler base
        
    *   [!The second UAV is located east of the swamp village <image:9793>](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/escapefromtarkov_gamepedia/images/5/5d/Secondshorelineuav.png/revision/latest?cb=20231228222352 "The second UAV is located east of the swamp village")
        
        The second UAV is located east of the swamp village
        
    *   [![The SAS disks can be found behind the side panels of the UAVs. [](https://www.fandom.com/)

**Eagle Eye** is a [Quest](/wiki/Quests "Quests")
 in _[Escape from Tarkov](/wiki/Escape_from_Tarkov "Escape from Tarkov")
_.

Contents
--------

*   [1 Dialogue](#Dialogue)
    
*   [2 Requirements](#Requirements)
    
*   [3 Objectives](#Objectives)
    
*   [4 Rewards](#Rewards)
    
*   [5 Guide](#Guide)
    

Dialogue\[[](https://auth.fandom.com/signin?redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fescapefromtarkov.fandom.com%2Fwiki%2FEagle_Eye%3Faction%3Dedit%26section%3D1&uselang=en "Sign in to edit")\
\]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Okay, next job. NATO has carefully studied the conflict even before the Blue Helmets force surge and sent several drones to recon. Two drones were shot down over the coast, now that getting to them has become possible, we can try to pull out the memory block from these. Find their impact locations and bring me the memory disks. Open up the panels to retrieve the disks
        
    *   [![Opened panel with disk](<Base64-Image-Removed>)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/escapefromtarkov_gamepedia/images/7/77/SAS_disk_in_drone.png/revision/latest?cb=20231228222559 "Opened panel with disk")
        
        Opened panel with disk
